awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides  support for 24 regional participants to attend "The Midwest Numerical Analysis Day", which will be held on April 14 to 15, 2018, on the campus of the University of Kansas, in Lawrence, Kansas. Funds will provide support for women, underrepresented minorities, and young participants (graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior faculty). Scientific computing is a rapidly growing multidisciplinary field and has become a common tool for using advanced computing capabilities to  construct mathematical models for complex problems, to develop quantitative analysis techniques, and to understand and solve the scientific problems arising from different disciplines. Numerical analysis is the core of scientific computing, an area that develops and studies algorithms of obtaining the numerical solutions of the mathematical models of real world problems. With the increasing power of modern computers, large scale and complex simulations become possible, which in turn requires collaboration among numerical analysts, algorithm designers, and exports in applied sciences and engineering. Such an interdisciplinary collaboration has increased significantly and become a new norm in last decades.

This conference will bring  groups  of researchers  in mathematics and applied sciences and engineering who are interested in scientific computation and related applications. It will facilitate a transfer of knowledge among different disciplines and promote the collaborations. The conference will provide an excellent opportunity for regional researchers in all stages of their careers, especially for young faculty members, postdocs, and graduate students, to present their research results,  have the opportunities to exchange the ideas with people from different disciplines, and gain experience and improve their skills in communication and presentation.  Moreover, the conference will invite, encourage, and support people from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

por.por_cntn:
This project provided a forum for researchers at all stages of their careers, mainly from the midwest region, to present their research results, exchange ideas, and foster collaborations. 


The project supported 
1) One conference: "Midwest Numerical Analysis Day" April 14-15, 2018. The conference website is https://mwnaday2018.ku.edu/.  There were 4 plenary talks, 14 non-plenary talks, 7 posters, and 40+ participants. 


The 4 plenary talks were


"Numerical linear algebra problems arising in network analysis" by Michele Benzi (Emory University)
"C0 interior penalty methods" by Susanne Brenner (Louisiana State University)
"Analysis of the dynamics of immersed elastic filaments in Stokes flow"  by Yoichiro Mori (University of Minnesota)
"Why spectral methods are preferred in PDE eigenvalue computations--in some cases?" by Zhimin Zhang (Wayne State University)


The contributed talks included different topics in numerical analysis, applied sciences, and engineering such as discontinuous Galerkin methods,  eigensolvers, mesh generation, numerical simulations for population model, ionic flow models. 


2)  One workshop: "KU Numerical Analysis Day" March 26, 2022. The workshop website is https://naday2022.ku.edu/. There were 12 talks, 7 posters, and 34 participants. The topics of the talks in the workshop included deep neural network, moving interfaces, spectral methods, mesh-free methods, and discontinuous Galerkin methods. 


The participants of both the conference and workshop  included senior researchers, young faculty members, postdoc and graduate students.  There were  poster sections, mainly presented by graduate students.
This project successfully provided affordable opportunities for regional researchers to present their research result, motivated the interdisciplinary collaborations, strengthened numerical analysis groups at universities in the midwest region.




Last Modified: 05/21/2022
Modified by: Xuemin Tu
